dt: {bc}any of various usually small, compact roses with large flowers in open clusters that derive from crosses of polyantha and tea roses

et: borrowed from New Latin, originally a specific epithet of various plants, from feminine of {it}flōribundus,{/it} apparently taken to mean "full of flowers, flowering freely," from Latin {it}flōrēre{/it} "to bloom" + {it}-bundus{/it} "carrying on (the activity denoted by the verb)" {ma}{mat|florescence|}{/ma}
The sense of the New Latin coinage appears to depend on allusion to Latin {it}abundāre{/it} "to be rich in, abound with" (see {et_link|abound|abound}).
shortdef: any of various usually small, compact roses with large flowers in open clusters that derive from crosses of polyantha and tea roses
